I.  THE PROPOSED PROJECT 
1.  The Asian Development Bank (ADB) seeks to provide a financial intermediation loan to 
Housing Construction Savings Bank of Kazakhstan (HCSBK) to expand the access of female 
borrowers to affordable mortgage finance. The assistance is planned to be provided as  a 
sovereign-guaranteed loan in local currency equivalent of up to $100 million to HCSBK. The ADB 
loan will help HCSBK address the unmet but growing demand for long-term, fixed-rate mortgage 
credit by using local currency funds to provide affordable mortgage finance to female borrowers. 
It will be ADB’s first-ever financial intermediation project in the country that targets exclusively 
women beneficiaries. 
 
2.  The proposed technical assistance (TA) grant will support HCSBK in its goal to improve 
access to affordable housing finance by women and expand financial inclusion for women in the 
country through capacity building services primarily involving the following actions: (i) improve 
financial literacy among potential women borrowers in Kazakhstan, (ii) raise awareness for 
gender-related lending aspects in HCSBK’s operations by hiring and training employees to 
become gender champions1 in its head office and some of its larger branches, (iii) assist in the 
implementation of a comprehensive gender action plan in HCSBK,2 and (iv) enhance HCSBK’s 
customer targeting by designing lending programs and products specific to women. 
 
3.  The project is consistent with ADB’s country partnership strategy for Kazakhstan, 2017–
2021, which prioritizes access to finance and inclusive growth as key pillars of assistance to 
strengthen foundations for economic diversification, envisaging support to facilitate access to 
finance for those in rural and remote areas.3 The project is included in ADB’s country operations 
business plan for Kazakhstan, 2019–2021.4 
 
II.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.    Justification  
 
4.  Kazakhstan has shown commitment to advancing gender equality and to engaging with 
the international community to demonstrate its gender development progress. In line with this 
commitment, Kazakhstan has developed a policy and legal framework that is designed to advance 
gender equality as a national goal. Kazakhstan has developed a long-term plan, outlined in its 
Strategy 2050,5 to join the thirty most developed countries by 2050. To reach its goal of a more 
rapid development, Kazakhstan is diversifying its economic base away from an overreliance on 
extractive  industries  toward  a  more  robust  small  and  medium-sized  enterprise  sector  and 
transforming itself into a hub of regional economic corridors. The government acknowledges the 
critical role of gender equality, and sees the potential to advance gender equality by promoting 
women’s labor force participation, pay equity, social protection, reduction of regional disparities, 
and assistance to vulnerable groups to be integrated into future economic and social development 
strategies. 
 
                                                
1  Experts in gender related financing aspects. 
2  Gender Action Plan (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 2 of the report and recommendation   
    of the President). 
3  ADB. 2017. Country Partnership Strategy: Kazakhstan, 2017–2021—Promoting Economic Diversification, Inclusive 
    Development, and Sustainable Growth. Manila. 
4  ADB. 2018. Country Operations Business Plan: Kazakhstan, 2019–2021. Manila. 
5  Government of Kazakhstan. 2012. Strategy “Kazakhstan- 2050”. Astana.

2   
 
5.  HCSBK and the Government of Kazakhstan requested the proposed transaction TA to 
support the government’s initiatives to expand access of female borrowers to affordable local 
currency  mortgage  finance  efficiently  and  in  a  timely  manner.  The  results  framework, 
implementation  arrangements,  cost  estimates,  and  the  scope  of  the  transaction  TA  were 
discussed with HCSBK and the government during the fact-finding mission. 
 
6.  The transaction TA will have the following primary outcomes: (i) a nationwide market study 
evaluating the current banking industry regarding access by women to housing finance products 
completed; (ii) the profile of women borrowers as a relevant and important business segment for 
HCSBK raised; and (iii) lending and/or deposit products exclusively aimed at women developed 
and efficiency of HCSBK’s lending to women borrowers improved. The TA cannot be funded by 
the proposed loan to HCSBK because targeting exclusively women borrowers (through the 
preparation of a nationwide market study and the development of new products geared at female 
customers) is a completely new market segment for HCSBK for which the bank does not have 
enough experience and expertise.6 
 
B.  Outputs and Activities 
 
7.  Output 1: Long-term affordable mortgage financing for eligible women borrowers 
made available. Under this output the TA will assist HCSBK in improving gender-related lending 
aspects in HCSBK’s operations through the following activities: (i) raise the profile of women 
borrowers as a relevant and important business segment for HCSBK, (ii) increase the volume of 
mortgage lending to women, and (ii) grow the percentage of HCSBK’s female mortgagors. 
 
8.  Output 2: Efficiency of HCSBK’s lending operations to women borrowers improved. 
The TA will help enhance HCSBK’s customer targeting by designing lending programs and 
products specific to women. Furthermore, the TA will help HCSBK adopt a gender policy. The TA 
will support HCSBK in raising public awareness of lending products exclusively aimed at women 
through (i) conducting special public campaigns to raise awareness among the female population 
in  Kazakhstan  for  the  availability  of  gender  specific  financing  products  and  programs,  (ii) 
conducting  seminars  on  the  use  of  gender  indicators  for  decision-making  and  product 
development, and (iii) training employees in its head office and regional branches to become 
gender champions (Footnote 1). 
 
9.  Output  3:  Gender-inclusiveness  of  the  banking  industry’s  housing  finance 
assessed. The TA will (i) prepare a comprehensive nationwide market study evaluating the 
banking industry regarding access by women to housing finance products, (ii) identify related 
constraints and issues, and (iii) estimate the demand and develop concrete ideas and financial 
products on how to increase financial inclusion from women borrowers. Furthermore, HCSBK, in 
partnership with the government, will organize a seminar to discuss the findings of the market 
study and agree on the way forward. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing  
 
10.  The TA is estimated to cost $620,000 and will be financed on a grant basis by ADB’s 
Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF–other sources.)7 The key expenditure items are listed 
in Appendix 1. 
                                                
6  The TA first appeared in the business opportunities section of ADB’s website on 8 May 2019.  
7  The Government of Kazakhstan contributed $120,000 to ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund to finance this  
    proposed transaction TA.

3 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
11.  The implementation arrangements for the transaction TA will be aligned with the proposed 
financial intermediary loan to HCSBK. ADB will select, supervise, and evaluate consultants and 
procure goods (if necessary). The Government of Kazakhstan, acting through the Ministry of 
National Economy, will be the executing agency, while HCSBK will be the implementing agency. 
The TA will be implemented from January 2020 to December 2021. 
 
12.  ADB will engage individual consultants and a consulting firm in accordance with the ADB 
Procurement Policy (2017, as amended from time to time) and the associated staff instructions. 
Disbursements under the TA will be done in accordance with ADB's Technical Assistance 
Disbursement Handbook (2010, as amended from time to time). ADB will select the consulting 
firm through the quality- and cost-based selection method with a standard quality–cost ratio of 
90:10. The estimated consultant inputs comprise 20 person-months of international, and 12 
person-months of national, consulting services. Output-based lump-sum consulting contracts will 
be preferred. The proposing entities may suggest some adjustments, with justification. Depending 
on the emerging circumstances, ADB will retain flexibility on the number and person-month 
allocations among the experts, as well as their tasks.
